These are my notes for the udemy course Next JS & React - The complete guide
React is a pre req. Next builds on top of it.
React is just a library. Why do we need another library that builds on top of it?
Next js a fullstack react framework.
It simplifies the process of building fullstack apps with react.
React itself has added more features like improved SSR, Streaming responses, React Server components, Server actions etc.
To build a full stack app, we need Routing, form submission, data fetching, authentication and more.
Next builds up on react & simplify the process of building full stack web apps with react.
data.key-features#Key features:
Just with JS, we build both front end and backend.
same project itself.
File system based Routing, not configuration or packages.
All contents (pages & components) visible on screen is rendered on server first and sends a finished page to client helping SEO.
Run npx create-next-app@latest to scaffold a next app.




We use App router instead of Page router.
navigate to the folder root and run npm run dev
data.react-vs-next#React vs Next:
If we inspect the page source, we see the actual finished page being sent from the server.
The actual content visible on the page was sent from server. This is not the case for a standard client app.
On a standard react app, we render a bare minimum frame and then manipulates it in the browser.
So react app is just a client side app, whereas next js is both server side & client side in one project.
With next, we have a full stack app that blends client & server side.
in Nextjs, page is a reserved keyword. Similarly, there are a lot of reserved names.
Anything within the app, is for the routing. If we need to create components, do it inside a components folder which is a sibling to the app folder.

app/

page.js // ==> loads localhost:3000/awesome if we export a standard react component
Keep in mind, it has to be a default export.

page router vs app router
both approaches help build full stack apps.

data.file-based-routing--server-components#Fi:
npm i and the npm run dev to run the app locally.
app is the most important folder. we sets up different pages within it.
page.js is a reserved name.
It is a server component. They are rendered only on server, never on client.
The component function is executed on server only.
the console is executed in terminal. If you check dev tools, we won't see it.
to add more pages, within app folder, we add about/ folder within which we add a page.js.
data.in-app-navigation#In-app navigation:
For navigation between pages within the app, we use next js link. Regular links refreshes the page.
With nextjs, when we visit a page for the first time, it is rendered on server , gets a finished page and we are here.
But if we are on a page, and we click around, next allows to stay in a SPA & update UI with help of client side JS code.
Technically, the content of the next page will still be pre-rendered on the server but updated on client side with client side JS code.
We get the best of both worlds, a highly interactive client side app, a finished page being served if we are visiting the page for first time.


import Link from 'next/link';

<Link href="/about"> About </Link>;
With regular anchor element, the page refreshes and we loose the app state.
data.reserved-names#Reserved names:
page.js      => Create a new page (e.g., app/about/page.js creates a <your-domain>/about page)
layout.js    => Create a new layout that wraps sibling and nested pages
not-found.js => Fallback page for "Not Found" errors (thrown by sibling or nested pages or layouts)
error.js     => Fallback page for other errors (thrown by sibling pages or nested pages or layouts)
loading.js   => Fallback page which is shown whilst sibling or nested pages (or layouts)
are fetching data
route.js     => Allows you to create an API route (i.e., a page which does NOT return JSX code
but instead data, e.g., in the JSON format)

data.how-is-the-application-getting-bootstrap:
Angular.json is the heart of the application
In angular.json, look at this portion
"root": "",
"sourceRoot": "src", // ðŸ‘ˆ means, the application source is held within this folder
"prefix": "app", // ðŸ‘ˆ means, the components will be prefixed with this word (app-root, app-header etc)
"architect": {
"build": {
"options": {
"index": "src/index.html", // ðŸ‘ˆ the only HTML sent across from server
"main": "src/main.ts", // ðŸ‘ˆ the first file compiler should look for.
"assets": [
"src/favicon.ico",
"src/assets"
],
"styles": [
"src/styles.scss" // ðŸ‘ˆ  custom styles which are imported dynamically in head as a link tag
],
"scripts": [] // ðŸ‘ˆ  extra javascript to be dynamically injected as a script tag
and within the index.html, we have a placeholder. The whole application will be rendered inside this placeholder div
<body>
<app-root></app-root>  // ðŸ‘ˆ whole app rendered inside this component
</body>


SPA flow,
browser sends an initial request to server
it responds with a minumum set of HTML, JS and css
Page renders with that shell
JS takes control
Then it renders the app within the placeholder, creates and swaps components to simulate page changes
makes api calls to get the respective data in JSON format to feed the components with data.

within this placeholder, whatever module the main points to, ( src/main.ts )the main.ts points to the AppModule
import { platformBrowserDynamic } from '@angular/platform-browser-dynamic';
import { AppModule } from './app/app.module';

platformBrowserDynamic()
.bootstrapModule(AppModule)
.catch((err) => console.error(err));
Angular has the concept of modules. ( which is a nice way of encapsulating functionalities into smaller focused bundles which can be brought into the application based on our requirements. ).The syntax above basically says, platformBrowserDynamic is a module that helps us take our application which is wrapped within the AppModule to loaded into browser. This step is done via platformBrowserDynamic and not directly injected into DOM like a jquery or javascript using document.querySelector or anything. That is because we need to make the application loosely coupled so that it can be plugged into browser as well as non browser environments. ( like Ionic which is used for building native mobile apps ). For such situation, instead of platformBrowserDynamic, we use the mobile equivalent method platformNativeScriptDynamic so that the bootstrapping is done right and there is no direct DOM dependency. We need our application to work on all environments ( browser, server, web worker, mobile device etc ).An angular application should contain atleast one module and within that one component ( With Angular 16, we have stand alone components which omits the use of modules though - More on that later )
The index.html is the only page that is served. There are dynamic scripts being injected in index.html of the served page, by cli automatically. These bundles are added automatically by the framework. The flow is angular.json -> main.ts -> starts / bootstraps the angular app by passing a module to this method. In app module, we registered the app.component as the bootstrap property. This is the first component that needs to be loaded. Angular framework changes the DOM at runtime.
data.standalone-components#Standalone compone:

we got a new way of building apps without modules. Concept wise, the fundamentals all remain as is, the difference being, instead of modules being used as containers, the idea is somewhat different.Example Angular 17 stand alone appThe standalone flag + imports array combo helps us register stand alone components.

In angular, or rather any framework that uses component based architecture,
We no longer see a page as a page, but we see tham as a bunch of re-usable components.
See the image below. We divide the page as a bunch of (nested) componentsThat's where the idea of composition comes into the picture.
data.you-think-about#You think about:
making the leanest possible component,
how can you customize them,
what all inputs can be passed, what all outputs need to be provided
how will component communicate with each other.
configure them,
reuse them
test them

That's what Single responsibility principle says. A component should ideally do just one thing, and one thing only. If it does more than one thing, then better split them into another component.
data.modules#Modules:
In angular, modules are basically wrappers that bundle the application into small packages. Note, there is something called typescript module too, which is not what i mean when i say "module" here in this context.Module becomes more important when we discuss about lazy loading towards the end where we discuss about optimizations. For better loading times, we keep the main app module lean, and thin, and via routing, we load subsequent portions of the application upon clicking the link which then loads its code as a small chunk ( ie bundle of js which is a small file which you can see in the Inspect / Network section ) and navigates to that part of the application.When the app grows, it becomes important to split them into meaningful modules so that we bundle the logic within respective modules and load them on demand. Don't just keep stuffing the app module with more and more logic. That hampers loading time, performance & affects scalability & maintainability.The whole angular functionalities has been split between various modules.
If you take a look at the package.json, we see many package dependencies. Each package holds certain logic which we use it via registering them within the imports: [] of the module when needed.
"dependencies": {
"@angular/animations": "^15.0.0", // ðŸ‘ˆ  all animation logic is within this module
"@angular/common": "^15.0.0", // ðŸ‘ˆ  common component logic is here
"@angular/compiler": "^15.0.0",
"@angular/core": "^15.0.0", // ðŸ‘ˆ  core angular functionality here
"@angular/forms": "^15.0.0", // ðŸ‘ˆ  forms related logic here
"@angular/platform-browser": "^15.0.0",
"@angular/platform-browser-dynamic": "^15.0.0",
"@angular/router": "^15.0.0",// ðŸ‘ˆ  routing logic here

Idea is to work without modules.
Introduced in Angular 14+
Its introduced in Preview mode for V14. So the syntax can change later. With V15, its stable.
That doesnt mean, we should use this in production ready apps.
Standard apps have one problem - Boilerplate code.
It makes refactoring painful.
Angular modules help organize & structure the code, but it comes with its own boilerplates.
To get rid of ngModules, angular brought Standalone modules.

ExampleThe new mode ( in preview ) can be mixed with old way.
In a regular component, add special flag standalone: true to the configuration of component.
If we mark a component as standalone, then do not register the component in any modules.
We must still let angular know of this component.
Go to the component where this component is used, add imports: [DetailsComponent]
or go to the AppModule, instead of adding the stand alone components to declarations, we add it to imports.
StandAlone directive is possible. ( standalone: true )
In stand alone component, we can add imports: [SharedModule]
In AppComponent, if we add standalone to true, which is the root component,  we need to change the main.ts to point to the component.


// platform browser

providers: [

],

We have 4 types of bindingsBy binding, we mean, a connection or a communication between template, which is the HTML  & class / business logic, which is the Typescript logic.

$event is a reserved keyword that passes the event data as a parameter when triggering event bindings.
By default, event.target.value returns a string. It is not angular related, but javascript specific.

data.explanation#Explanation:
Here, we are having a custom property called user for the UserComponent to which we pass a user instance down from the parent & a custom event OnSelect

<app-user

we have an onSelect which is an EventEmitter which emits the event to the immediate parent.
In a uni-directional pattern, data flows down, events flow up.
So long as the logic is handled by parent, child just need to obey what it is told to do.
the decision making is delegated to parent. We pass a user down, and when the user is selected, we emit that up.
What parent does with that info is not child's concern. It can log the value, add it to collection, or show a notification. Whatever it is.

data.change-detection#Change detection:
angular's change detection mechanism.
OnPush, signals, zoneless.
By default, we have a component tree, angular wraps the tree with zones.
Zone.js is a third party library
If a user clicks a button, angular is notified, it starts the CD process, visits all components in the application, takes a look at all templates & its bindings and checks whether it produces a new value.
If it does, the real DOM is updated with the new value.
getters get executed a lot. So be careful with it.
Same logs gets logged twice in development. Change detection runs twice. Its a dev mode feature
detects unwanted changes that may gets trggered after the change detection being completed.
If the value is not same between 2 cycles, angular throws the error.

data.build-for-production#Build for productio:
There are issues with caching
npm run build does a prod build. Then run it with npm run start
if we run that and revisit the meals page, adding a new meal brings a small problem.
When redirected, the meal which we added is missing.
Next performs caching. With production, next js pre renders all the pages of the app which can be pre-generated.
So basically, all non dynamic pages are pre generated.
Next caches the pre rendered pages. Downside being, it never refetches the meals. So newly entered data is lost.
Because the code never executes again. It uses the pre rendered pages itself.

When we enter the data, we need to store them in a database.
Option 1 is to have a standalone backend, a separate one that recives request from next js app and store/mutate data. But this is overly complex and unnecessary extra server.
Option 2 is to have an integrated nextjs app. The app itself contains the data mutation code & reach out to data stores directly.
